Bug.Summery: [resources] Resources names in file system are not i18n (file.encoding problem)
Bug.WithStack:
If i setup Baltik languages and Latvian locale, then files and folders in OS appears to be wrongly named.
For example, if i create a project named in latvian with special letters (you can enter them by right Alt and a letter on keyboard), then they are displayed correctly in eclipse view, but not in OS file system. This is not a problem of OS, as soon as i can enter files and folders names in OS directly.
Moreover, file properties displays file path correctly.
This was revealed when trying to export/import this project, as soon as it failed to export by Browse button. But if i enter path manually (with correct project name) then it is imported.
Look attach picture
Note: i have 4 languages active in my OS: latvian, bulgarian, english, russian. Created attachment 3121 Workspace, file system and project properties Additional investigation showed that it happens when default language does not correspond computer locale. Defaulkt language effects in file.encoding JVM property. If you try create resources NOT in file.encoding codepage Eclipse convert characters and that is bad.
Seems like Eclipse creates file names not in UTF8? More precisely: When some strings collected by eclipse is going to be filenames, they are transformed into byte arrays with String.getBytes() or so. This getBytes() uses default encoding, set in file.encoding property. This property is set by JVM on startup to current windows locale. It is usually non-UNICODE encoding (such as Cp1251). Eclipse should depending on underlying OS use UNICODE-encoding where possible (UTF-8, UTF-16, USC-2...) (I dont quite remember which one is to be used in Windows 2000/XP). So you need to use getBytes("UTF-16") or so everywhere in output to filesystem. Could you please inform which Eclipse build and JRE provider/version you are using?
Some VMs do not handle file names containing characters not supported in the default encoding properly on Windows 2K/XP. Eclipse uses the core Java APIs and native calls for creating file/folders and listing directory contents. 1.4 level VMs seem to support files containing any Unicode characters properly (if the OS provides support).
However, before build 20030205, Eclipse didn't handle those files properly even when running on 1.4 level VMs (see bug 13163).
Could you try this build with a 1.4-level VM to see if the problem persists? Thanks. We are using Sun java 1.3.1_06. Sorry but we NEED it to work on 1.3.1 (as soon as eclipse declares 1.3 support and we rely on this declaration in our work). And this problem certanly can be fixed by eclipse developers. Look my previous comment and just fix one string in your java code. Forget to give you eclipse build: we are using eclipse 2.0.1 release (build 200208291828) Denis, we don't do any encoding when creating files and folders, we just call the standard Java I/O API passing Java strings (which are Unicode). So, although Eclipse supports 1.3 level JREs, we cannot overcome all bugs in the underlying JRE that avoid Eclipse of working properly.
The good news is that this bug seems to be fixed in the new Sun JRE 1.3.1_07.
From JavaSoft's bug parade:
java.io: Cannot create files with full Unicode names (Win32/NT) http://developer.java.sun.com/developer/bugParade/bugs/4185525.html
Please let us know if the problem goes away using the new VM. I could verify that Sun JDK/JRE 1.3.1_07 seems to effectively fix the problem. By the way, the bug I intended to refer to before (see comment 4) was actually bug 13463 (whose fix now works also on this new JRE).
DJ, I suggest this bug to be closed as works-for-me. Closing.

Bug.Summery: [Import/Export] Import existing project from file system enter path problem

Lines.Line: 1. Import attached PDE projects or create your projects with equal start part
2. Select each imported PDE project and choose Export->File System, choose the
path and enter the name name of exported project at the end of path (for
3. Delete projects (with contents) through PDE perspective.
4. Choose File->Import->Existing Project into Workspace. Press Browse button
and select project with longer name - PDE_pj_02.
5. Press Browse button again and select project PDE_pj.
Defect: Project name is not refreshed. Previous project name is displayed in
the Project name field of Import editor. Therefore when Finish is pressed
incorrect project is imported into workspace.
Please verify if this is still an issue Stefan

Bug.WithStack:
When path for project imported from file system is entered manually (not using Browser button) then it stick on the first found project. For example, if i have folder structure and in intermediate folder there is a .project file it sticks on it and even if i enter then full path it enters that project. Look attached picture and zipped copy of folder Created attachment 3122 Now project2 folder selected, while it going to import project1 Created attachment 3123 Zip of folder from where projects imported Another use case related to (probably) this bug... Execution steps: 1. Import attached PDE projects or create your projects with equal start part of projects` names. 2. Select each imported PDE project and choose Export->File System, choose the path and enter the name name of exported project at the end of path (for example "c:\test\<exported project name>"). 3. Delete projects (with contents) through PDE perspective. 4. Choose File->Import->Existing Project into Workspace. Press Browse button and select project with longer name - PDE_pj_02. 5. Press Browse button again and select project PDE_pj. Defect: Project name is not refreshed. Previous project name is displayed in the Project name field of Import editor. Therefore when Finish is pressed incorrect project is imported into workspace. Please verify if this is still an issue Stefan Fixed long ago.

Bug.Summery: Would like a way to navigate back from debugger to corresponding launch config
Bug.WithStack:
Build 20030123
When willing to check the launch config, I have to manually figure what I am running at the moment, where I believe it should allow me to find out the exact launch config I used to trigger this execution. Do you mean you want to navigate from a debug element (stack frame, thread, target, launch) to the launch config dialog? Fixed. Please verify, Joe (S).
I have added an action to the context menu in the debug view to open the launch dialog on the config associated with the selected debug element/process/launch. The action is named "XXX..." where XXX is the name of the associated config, and the icon is that of the launch config type. Nice feature. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build 20030123
When willing to check the launch config, I have to manually figure what I am running at the moment, where I believe it should allow me to find out the exact launch config I used to trigger this execution. Do you mean you want to navigate from a debug element (stack frame, thread, target, launch) to the launch config dialog? Fixed. Please verify, Joe (S).
I have added an action to the context menu in the debug view to open the launch dialog on the config associated with the selected debug element/process/launch. The action is named "XXX..." where XXX is the name of the associated config, and the icon is that of the launch config type. Nice feature. Verified.

3. RESULTS ON WINDOWS 2000
Results on Windows 2000 (If I have copied it correctly) >java -classpath ..\..\aspectj1.1\lib\aspectjrt.jar;. test.Test3 test.Test3@1a8c4e7.x:=-3 Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException at test.Log.ajc$afterReturning$test_Log$30d(Test3.java:37) at test.Test3.main(Test3.java:8) >java -version java version "1.4.1_01" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.1_01-b01) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.1_01-b01, mixed mode) java This is now fixed in the current cvs tree with a test in bugs/crashes.
This was a fascinating bug, and you did an excellent job of reducing it to a minimal test case. The problem had to do with ajc's attempts to optimize away the creation of dynamic JoinPoint objects, which can be very expensive. Your code managed to confuse this optimization and caused it to generate a call to the method ThisJoinPoint.StaticPart.getSignature on an object that was statically typed to ThisJoinPoint. This is illegal bytecode.
You should consider reporting this as a bug to SUN. While ajc did generate illegal bytecode here, the correct VM behavior should have been to produce a VerifyError when loading the classes. Neither the Solaris or Windows VM is handling this case at all well. The Solaris VMs behavior is particularly troubling as it causes such a hard crash.
Bug.WithOutStack:
This program causes the java VM to crash. It is a minimal example -- if you remove anything in the aspects it works.
1. PROGRAM CODE
package test; import org.aspectj.lang.*; import org.aspectj.lang.reflect.*;
public class Test3 { public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { Test3 a = new Test3(); a.foo(-3); } public void foo(int i) { this.x=i; } int x;
}
aspect Log { pointcut assign(Object newval, Object targ): set(* test..*) && args(newval) && target(targ);
before(Object newval, Object targ): assign(newval,targ) { Signature sign = thisJoinPoint.getSignature(); System.out.println(targ.toString() + "." + sign.getName() + ":=" + newval); } /* } // Different error message if you divide into two aspects aspect Tracing { */ pointcut tracedCall(): call(* test..*(..))/* && !within(Tracing)*/ && !within(Log);
after() returning (Object o): tracedCall() { // Works if you comment out either of these two lines thisJoinPoint.getSignature(); System.out.println(thisJoinPoint); } }

Bug.Summery: [Preferences] editors preferences not stored on OK?
Bug.WithStack:
20030121 my eclipse hard-crashed and it seems that the 'number of open editors' preference was lost
preference pages should store their values on OK. i guess the 'Editors' page forgot to do it. Preferences are stored on OK - this is likely a problem with the preference page. Turned out to be indicative of a larger problem - nothing using a AbstractUIPluginPreference store was being saved. Well spotted Adam.
Fixed in build > 20030124 Marking closed
Bug.WithOutStack:
20030121 my eclipse hard-crashed and it seems that the 'number of open editors' preference was lost
preference pages should store their values on OK. i guess the 'Editors' page forgot to do it. Preferences are stored on OK - this is likely a problem with the preference page. Turned out to be indicative of a larger problem - nothing using a AbstractUIPluginPreference store was being saved. Well spotted Adam.
Fixed in build > 20030124 Marking closed

Bug.Summery: Wilcard searches not returning correct results
Bug.WithStack:
Searching for alphanumeric strings in the form CMN00000E returned these results:
CMN files found all occurrences of CMN are highlighted CMN? nothing found CMN* nothing found "CMN" nothing found
StoreOpenCmd - returns 3 files containing StoreOpenCmd (correct result) StoreOpen* - returns nothing StoreOpen? - returns nothing "StoreOpenCmd" - returns 3 files containing StoreOpenCmd (correct result)
search strings containing punctuation marks are not correctly highlighted Explanation: returns results highlighting appropriately "Explanation:" returns the same files results are not highlighted When searching in English, use lower case for search string CMN* - type cmn* StoreOpen* - type storeopen*
"Explanation:" - puntuation is ignored by the search engine, even when doing exact search, hence the document containing Explanation might be found, while it should not. Highlighting exact search terms does not ignore punctuation, therefore Explanation not highlighted in that document. With 2.1 it will be possible not to require wildcard queries be lowercase Fixed. CMN* should find document containing CMN00000E I'm using a 2.1 build and CMN* does not return anything. The fix was just release in the repository. Please check the nightly build or the M5 build (later next week).

Bug.Summery: Override/Implement Methods static function
Bug.WithStack:
The Override/Implement Methods functionality does not show static methods. It would be nice if it would be possible to override them too. in Java, non-virtual (private or static) methods cannot be overriden.
what's the sementics you would expect in this case? Created attachment 3124 Main Java file Created attachment 3125 Base Java file Created attachment 3126 Inherited Java file
This seems to compile perfectly with Java 1.4. Didn't test it with 1.3 though By the way, the place where I use this functionality seems to internally implemented using reflection. So indeed, this is not a very common approach. Mmh, looking at it this way it might not be interesting to let Override/Implement method support this, sorry for bothering you. Ok, closing.

4. Select the "Use project name as module name" and Finish
5. Select the project at the Synchonize view
6. Right-click the project and select Commit...
Then I got the error dialog box. We cannot commit the DBCS project correctly.
2) In sync view, select the project and choose Add to Version Control (which
3) In sync view, select the project and choose Commit (which fails)

Bug.WithStack:
CVS Server: AIX 1.11.2, linux 1.11.3 Driver: I20030122 Java : IBM Java 1.3.1 SR-3 Client Platform : WindowsXP (JP, KO, TCH, SCH) RedHat 8.0 (JP, KO, TCH, SCH)
We got the error dialog box when committing the DBCS project name into the CVS repository eventhough the CVS client and the server used the same encoding.
Steps: (Client: Windows XP Japanese, Server: AIX Ja_JP, cvs version: 1.11.2) 1. Create a project using DBCS characters 2. Right-click the project and select Team -> Share project... 3. Select the CVS repository 4. Select the "Use project name as module name" and Finish 5. Select the project at the Synchonize view 6. Right-click the project and select Commit... Then I got the error dialog box. We cannot commit the DBCS project correctly. Created attachment 3127 The erro dialog box
Please see the attached file. I believe this problem is due to a bug in the commit caused by unadded resources. To verify, perform an Add to Version Control on all outgoing additions before you commit. If this succeeds, then the problem is due to a bug that is already fixed. If this fails, please append additional details. We also have the same problem for the DBCS Folder name and File name. After Add a version control and commit, we got the same error. Just to clearify, did you perform the following steps:
1) Share project as described originally
2) In sync view, select the project and choose Add to Version Control (which suceeded).
3) In sync view, select the project and choose Commit (which fails)
Is the error message the same as the one origically posted or are other files involved (i.e. is it all the files in the project or just some of them).
Also, could you perform steps 2 and 3 in the Navigator and see if you get the same result (for step 2, you will need to select each file individually). I performed the steps you mentioned, I got the same error during commiting the project in the sync view(Step 3). For step3 in Navigator, I got the another error dialog. (I will attach the screenpicture.)
In addition, I started the following command (java -classpath startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main). After I commited the DBCS project, I tried to check these files in CVS perspective(Go to CVS perspective, Select CVS Server and Click the HEAD). I got the messages at the console and a .log file. Please see it.
Unhandled exception caught in event loop. Reason: String index out of range: -16 Created attachment 3149 The screen caputure of error dialog
This is the error dialog box (Step3 in the Navigator). Created attachment 3150 the .log file
This is the .log file. Fix released to HEAD. I confirmed this problem was fixed with the I20030129 build, but I got an another problem when using the DBCS project name. I will open a new defect fot it. In korea environment, still problem occurred. Please ignore my previous comment. The problem did not occur in korean environment. Please change the status to resolved, then I will close this. Reclosing Confirmed

Bug.Summery: NPE during build
Bug.WithStack:
While investigating bug 24793, I need to bring PDE-UI source into my workspace. Doing so, I encountered an NPE.
* My workspace contained ant & debug plug-ins as source * The other plug-ins were imported into my workspace as binaries * I turned off auto-build * Deleted the org.eclipse.pde.ui plugin (and removed contents from disk) * Added org.eclipse.pde.ui as source from CVS * Turned on auto-build * Got NPE
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.resources 4 2 Jan 24, 2003 08:59:11.97 !MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug- in: "org.eclipse.core.resources". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.pde.internal.core.PDECore.findPlugin(PDECore.java:191) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.validateRequires (ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:251) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.validateValues (ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:229) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.validatePlugin (ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:167) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.checkFile (ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:127) at org.eclipse.pde.internal.builders.ManifestConsistencyChecker.build (ManifestConsistencyChecker.java:83) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$2.run (BuildManager.java:384) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild (BuildManager.java:120) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild (BuildManager.java:176) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild (BuildManager.java:186) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager$1.run (BuildManager.java:146) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.Platform.run(Platform.java(Compiled Code)) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.basicBuild (BuildManager.java:160) at org.eclipse.core.internal.events.BuildManager.build (BuildManager.java:211) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.build (Workspace.java:174) at org.eclipse.ui.actions.GlobalBuildAction$1.run (GlobalBuildAction.java:154) at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run (ModalContext.java:95) A full build seems to have put me back on track. We know about this defect - Wassim, please resolve it as a duplicate to the one you fixed. This bug is fixed in the I-22030122 build.

Bug.Summery: org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor is confusing

source_code.code: // Add rule for single line comments.
// Add rule for single line comments.

Bug.WithStack:
Based on the lack of documentation to implement custom syntax highlighting for Eclipse, I was expecting org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor to be better documented and thought out.
For instance, the example fails to make a clear distinction between a JavaCodeScanner and a JavaPartitionScanner. In fact, you can even see duplicated information. For example, if you wanted to change the example so that comments until the end of the line started with ";" instead of "//", where would you make the change ? JavaCodeScanner ? JavaPartitionScanner ? Both ?
JavaCodeScanner has this: // Add rule for single line comments. rules.add(new EndOfLineRule("//", comment)); //$NON-NLS-1$
JavaPartitionScanner has this: // Add rule for single line comments. rules.add(new EndOfLineRule("//", Token.UNDEFINED)); //$NON- NLS-1$
Are both really needed ? Why do I need to specify the same information in 2 separate places ? Is it a problem with the JFace design or with the example ?
How about better comments, explaining the "whys" ? See JavaDoc of IDocument and IDocumentPartitioner for partitioning and IPresentationReconciler for syntax highlighting. This will help you understand the relationship between the serveral scanners.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Based on the lack of documentation to implement custom syntax highlighting for Eclipse, I was expecting org.eclipse.ui.examples.javaeditor to be better documented and thought out.
For instance, the example fails to make a clear distinction between a JavaCodeScanner and a JavaPartitionScanner. In fact, you can even see duplicated information. For example, if you wanted to change the example so that comments until the end of the line started with ";" instead of "//", where would you make the change ? JavaCodeScanner ? JavaPartitionScanner ? Both ?
JavaCodeScanner has this: // Add rule for single line comments. rules.add(new EndOfLineRule("//", comment)); //$NON-NLS-1$
JavaPartitionScanner has this: // Add rule for single line comments. rules.add(new EndOfLineRule("//", Token.UNDEFINED)); //$NON- NLS-1$
Are both really needed ? Why do I need to specify the same information in 2 separate places ? Is it a problem with the JFace design or with the example ?
How about better comments, explaining the "whys" ? See JavaDoc of IDocument and IDocumentPartitioner for partitioning and IPresentationReconciler for syntax highlighting. This will help you understand the relationship between the serveral scanners.

Did the decorators appear in any non-Java views, like the navigator? *** Bug 30177 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Yes, the decorators do appear in the Navigator. This is a thread safety issue with the fast resource visitor. Investigating. Fixed. The problem was that the initialization of the fast visitor tree was not thread safe. There is a small critical region in DeltaDataTree.copyCompleteSubtree
We now acquire the workspace lock (WorkManager.checkIn()/checkOut() while the visitor tree is being initialized. This will create slightly more contention for the workspace lock, but is necessary to ensure we are thread safe. The performance hit is minimal assuming there is no contention for the workspace lock.

!SESSION Jan 24, 2003 10:43:04.390 --------------------------------------------- java.fullversion=J2RE 1.3.0 IBM build cn130-20010502 (JIT enabled: jitc) BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -dev bin -data c:\eclipse- ws\ui-ws -install file:C:/eclipse/ !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.workbench 4 2 Jan 24, 2003 10:43:04.390 !MESSAGE Problems occurred when invoking code from plug- in: "org.eclipse.ui.workbench". !STACK 0
I looks like it may be related to Java views. Did the decorators appear in any non-Java views, like the navigator? *** Bug 30177 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Yes, the decorators do appear in the Navigator. This is a thread safety issue with the fast resource visitor. Investigating. Fixed. The problem was that the initialization of the fast visitor tree was not thread safe. There is a small critical region in DeltaDataTree.copyCompleteSubtree
We now acquire the workspace lock (WorkManager.checkIn()/checkOut() while the visitor tree is being initialized. This will create slightly more contention for the workspace lock, but is necessary to ensure we are thread safe. The performance hit is minimal assuming there is no contention for the workspace lock.

Bug.Summery: Add "Open File" command similar to "Open Type"
Bug.WithStack:
The "Open Type" is one of the most usefull features in Eclipse, but it applies only to Java types. Can something similar to be done for any file that can be found in work space. This could be a very usefull feature, for anybody who have a large number of file in the workspace (in my case we are talking about more that 30k number).
Thank You navigate -> go to > resource works for me That is exactly what I was looking for. Thank You

Bug.Summery: Stale launch if runtime-workbench launch is canceled

Lines.Line: 1) Define a runtime-workbench launch config that has dulicate plugins (same
plugin in workspace and in external location).
3) When the warning dialog comes up about duplicate plugins, hit cancel.

Bug.WithStack:
Build: I20030122
1) Define a runtime-workbench launch config that has dulicate plugins (same plugin in workspace and in external location). 2) Launch this configuration 3) When the warning dialog comes up about duplicate plugins, hit cancel.
Observe: the runtime workbench process still exists in the debug view. It can't be terminated or removed. Re-assigning to JDT debug to get Darin's input: If the user launches a runtime workbench configuration contains duplicate plug- ins, PDE indicates that to the user through a warning dialog. If the user presses Cancel on that dialog, PDE terminates the launch using launch.terminate (). The launch terminates fine if the launch was originated from the launch configuration dialog. If the launch had been originated through a shortcut, we run into the problem that John outlined, i.e. the launch effectively terminates, but you will still see it in the debug view as active(without threads) and you cannot explicitly remove it or terminate it.
Does the launch.terminate() have different behaviors depending on how the launch originated? Can also be reproduced if there is a syntax error in a plugin.xml file and, when prompted, you hit cancel. In the WorkbenchLaunchConfigurationDelegate.launch, for duplicates or for failed validation etc., instead of terminating the launch (which does nothing as no processes or debug targets have been created yet) you should set the monitor to be cancelled and return (the user has cancelled the launch). As well, the launch configuration code will not waste time setting up the source lookup.
I have changed to clean up like when the launch originates from the launch configuration dialog. That is to remove the launch if it has no children. Darin, please verify my changes to LaunchConfiguration.
Wassim, things will work as is but I would recommend making the changes described in WorkspaceLaunchConfigurationDelegate. I'm not sure I agree with the changes... If a launch delegate were to populate a launch asynchronously (i.e. had a non-blocking launch method), the launch we be removed quiently without the delegate's knowledge. I beleive a safer fix is for the PDE launcher simply to set the launch as cancelled in the progress monitor. Ok I rolled back the changes, but don't we have that same possibility that pre- existed in the LaunchConfigurationDialog.launchWithProgress? AT my end, replacing launch.terminate() with monitor.setCanceled(true) seems to produce the desired behavior. Fixed up in LaunchConfigurationsDialog to not remove launches that are asynchronously adding children to the launch.
Please verify (DarinW). note that these changes rely on PDE updating to use the monitor.setCanceled (true) for the stale launches to be removed. These changes will be in the next integration build. Verified code.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Build: I20030122

Bug.Summery: Package Explorer doesn't remember its view [package explorer]
Bug.WithStack: When you select "Go Into" for a particular package and then shut down eclipse and start it up the package explorer shows you the root package again. It doesn't remember into which packages you had gone. It would be nice not to have to click "Go Into" every time you start up eclipse. Since we remember other state we should remember the Go Into state as well. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
Bug.WithOutStack: When you select "Go Into" for a particular package and then shut down eclipse and start it up the package explorer shows you the root package again. It doesn't remember into which packages you had gone. It would be nice not to have to click "Go Into" every time you start up eclipse. Since we remember other state we should remember the Go Into state as well. As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: line number info missing in compiled code by eclipse
Bug.WithStack:
When attempting to use the Remote debug feature with weblogic 7.0, I select to attach to the server started in debug mode, and I get an error message from Eclipse stating that there is not any line number information in the compiled code. This happened while using M4 version of eclipse. I have also specfied in the properties to set line number info in compiled code. In which code does the debugger claim the line info is missing? I.e. the compiler only puts debug info into your source files, not into existing binary libraries. e-mail from Joe Daughtery:
The exact messages is as follows: <BEGIN> Attempting to install a breakpoint in the type com.sss.swes.ClassName that has no line number attributes. The breakpoint cannot be installed. Class files must be generated with the line number attributes. Reason: Absent Line Number Information <END>
Also, the name of the Error Window which this error is displayed in is "Java Breakpoint".
You are simply compiling the class files? there is no byte code modification going on while the class is loaded? (See similar bug 28040). e-mail from Joe Daughtery:
Bug 28040 is exactly what is happening. Has there been any resolution to this problem? If not, I will go back to using M3.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 28040 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
When attempting to use the Remote debug feature with weblogic 7.0, I select to attach to the server started in debug mode, and I get an error message from Eclipse stating that there is not any line number information in the compiled code. This happened while using M4 version of eclipse. I have also specfied in the properties to set line number info in compiled code. In which code does the debugger claim the line info is missing? I.e. the compiler only puts debug info into your source files, not into existing binary libraries. e-mail from Joe Daughtery:
The exact messages is as follows: <BEGIN> Attempting to install a breakpoint in the type com.sss.swes.ClassName that has no line number attributes. The breakpoint cannot be installed. Class files must be generated with the line number attributes. Reason: Absent Line Number Information <END>
Also, the name of the Error Window which this error is displayed in is "Java Breakpoint".
You are simply compiling the class files? there is no byte code modification going on while the class is loaded? (See similar bug 28040). e-mail from Joe Daughtery:
Bug 28040 is exactly what is happening. Has there been any resolution to this problem? If not, I will go back to using M3.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 28040 ***

Bug.Summery: Compiler warning/error for dangerous switch/case
Bug.WithStack:
I'd like to see an additional (optional) error/warning generated by the compiler when switch/case is used in a dangerous way, that is, when case parts are not terminated by a break or return statement. While there will surely be lots of "old school" C-type hackers that happily make use of this "feature", I consider it bad style and error-prone. My experience is that it's usually a bug. And since it's so hard to find it, because everything compiles fine, it would be nice to have the compiler enforce a better programming style by issuing a warning here. If you do support this, please consider that the following case with multiple case labels for the same code still needs to work:
switch(..) { case 1: case 2: case 3: ... } Nice to have. Will reconsider post 2.1 If we report these, we should also consider allowing them if there is a comment which explicitely states the fall through scenario.
case 1: ... // fallthrough case 2: ...
Any comment would do the trick. *** Bug 43481 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** In 1.5 mode, these warnings should be suppressible by a @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough ") annotation. Time permitting, but likely beyond 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 67836 ***

Bug.Summery: Default settings for adding new files in CVS commit dialog
Bug.WithStack:
The CVS commit dialog's new ability to remind me of files that are not in CVS yet is a nice idea, but marking all these files as "to be added" by default is a bit dangerous. I think it's more secure to mark none of these file by default, so that no garbage makes it into CVS once I press "OK" too quickly. This is a hotly debated topic :)
I understand your argument and actually that was my position too. On the other hand, there are so many facilities for filtering out ignored resources that by the time you get to this dialog you probably only have left resources you would want to add. Basically, people found they were erring in the other direction, and forgetting to add resources to version control.
If you feel strongly about this please reopen, although unless really strong arguments are made I suspect we'll end up leaving it as is. We typically don't have un-ignored resources that aren't added to version control, but maybe your usage is different.
Btw, I would prefer *not* to make the default configurable. Closing this bug since we have a lot open and aren't planning on changing the behaviour (not because I didn't think your argument had value :> ).
Ok, here we go:
Argument 1: The default dialog options should always be the ones that result in least damage. A variation of the principle of least surprise.
- Stuff that doesn't make it into CVS although it should might be a problem or may even be annoying, but it can be corrected with a simple second commit.
- Stuff that has made it into CVS although it shouldn't, is a greater pain, because it will also flood the machines of all other project participants on their next update. Ok, you can correct even that by deleting resources from CVS. But in the case of using something like SourceForge, once the wrong file (say, a password file) has made it into the public CVS by mistake, you never have a chance to really correct this problem, because the SF policy assures that your stuff stays open source (in the CVS attic, if nowhere else) until armageddon. For me, this is reason enough to not want "put everything into CVS" as the default.
Argument 2: The world is full of stupid people that actually produce the problem described in argument 1. Or, expressed a bit more diplomatic: It occurs that you have to work on projects with other people that might not have the same experience with or insight into Eclipse or CVS management as yourself. These people tend to press OK buttons because they expect that it will do no harm, especially if there are no explicit warnings. The current dialog behavior makes it much too easy for these folks to flood my disk with temporary files, note files, backups, unpacked documentation etc.
Argument 3: Yes, I tend to have lots of (temporary and other) files in some of my projects that I want neither in CVS nor in .cvsignore (because the files are not always the same ones, so .cvsignore would become bigger and bigger over time). It happens that these files appear when running certain kinds of Ant tasks or when executing the application under development, although I must admit that maybe my way of dealing with the workspace is "non standard" here. But I'm used to it.
Argument 4: Filtering doesn't always help. In particular since I want all the files to appear in the tasks list to remind me of things to clean up. But I don't want them to go into CVS by default.
Simple suggestion: How about giving users a chance to turn the whole new feature off in the preferences, so that the commit dialog resembles the 2.1 one? That would be perfectly fine for me, and it should be easy to implement as well.
Btw: Count the latter suggestion as +1 for at least two people, because an Eclipse-using friend of mine who's too lazy to write his own bug reports totally agrees with me in that point. Trust me. :-)
We have made recent changes in this area. Could you let us know what build your using so we know we're talking about the same thing. (i.e. in the latest integration build, if the user commits with unadded resources in the selection, they are prompted twice: once to add unadded resource and once for the commit. Before that the dialog hade the comment and unadded resources in the same dialog and before that the unadded resources were skipped).
I agree with Kevin that a preference is not the best solution. I would propose the following. If a user has unadded resources when they commit, they are first prompted with the statement/question something like "you have unadded resources in the selection. Would you like to add and commit them?". Their choices would be to add them (Yes), skip them (No), Cancel or select files individually (Details). This is similar to what we had in 2.0 for commiting from the sync view with the added ability to select files individually. I am currently using M4, but could give one of the integration builds a shot, if you think I should. Yet, the additional dialog you mentioned doesn't make much of a difference, in my opinion. It's still a second button I have to press when committing, and the choice between YES and NO is not so far away from SELECT ALL and DESELECT ALL -- there's still plenty of room for pressing the wrong button. The latter in particular if you are in a hurry and have to quickly commit things that are needed by someone else (which seems to be true most of the time, in my case).
Also, as I wrote, I usually have files in my workspace that are neither under CVS control nor in .cvsignore, so I'd always see this dialog. I'd prefer to explicitly add files to CVS before I press commit. Maybe it's because I'm used to that from command line CVS for quite a while now.
Question: Even if you support the dialog you mentioned, why is it so hard to have an additional option "Prompt for new files on commit" in the CVS settings that, when turned off, results in the same commit behavior as in 2.0.x? I have no problem with this option being turned on by default, so that new Eclipse users have some kind of assistance when using CVS. To make it clear: I am not talking about a preference for choosing between "SELECT ALL" or "SELECT NONE" by default, the preference should decide whether Eclipse reminds me of files to add to CVS at all (during commit, that is, the tasks should stay as they are, of course).
>>Btw: Count the latter suggestion as +1 for at least two people, because an >>Eclipse-using friend of mine who's too lazy to write his own bug reports >>totally agrees with me in that point. Trust me. :-)
People who are too lazy to submit bug reports don't get a vote :)
Thanks for the notes. We have discussed but this may not be addressed until post 2.1 (due to time constraints and bug load). This bug has not been touched for 2 years. Closing as WONTFIX. Please reopen if you feel this is still an important issue.

Bug.Summery: NLS of Ant editor xml files
Bug.WithStack:
ECLIPSE\PLUGINS\ORG.ECLIPSE.UI.EXTERNALTOOLS_2.1.0\EXTERNALTOOLS_JAR\ ANTTASKS_1.5B.XML XML-10 969 (W) XML tag attribute (name) may contain translatable text which cannot be translated. Line: 8569 TASKS.XML XML-10 962 '<?xml' declaration must be defined in line 1, column 1. Line: 1 973 '<?xml' declaration must be the first XML statement. Line: 1 XDOCTASKS.XML XML-10 962 '<?xml' declaration must be defined in line 1, column 1. Line: 1 969 (W) XML tag attribute (name) may contain translatable text which cannot be translated. Line: 6502 973 '<?xml' declaration must be the first XML statement. Line: 1 These errors: <?xml' declaration must be defined in line 1, column 1. Line: 1 are easy to fix and have been.
The externalization of the rest of these files is a big question? *** Bug 30188 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Chkpii errors have been removed (by releng filtering). NLS remains as an open issue. Do not intend to NLS content assist files. Talking with Kevin Haaland, we need to internalized the anttasks_1.6.0.xml file. Specifically the content assist descriptions that are presented to the user. My $0.002 -> Don't externalize strings that the code from apache.ant gives you. The right place for this work to be done is in the Apache project. If you can demonstrate that these strings are extracted from apache and you are simply reusing them and by extension, if Apache were to externalize their code eclipse would also benefit. I'd defer this defect again for 3.0
Really a problem for the Apache Ant codebase.

Bug.Summery: IField:delete deletes too much
JUnit Results View -- Can't find Test suites when using TestSuite(Class, String) constructor [JUnit]

Lines.Line: 1. Create a TestCase that looks like:
2. With it selected, click on {The Running Man}->Run As->JUnit Test
3. In the JUnit Test Results view, click on the "Hierarchy" tab.
4. Double click on "The Dummy Test". You should get a message box saying
Test class not found in project
5. Double click on the failed test "testDummy" -- you should have the editor
7. Double click on the "warning" (that there are no tests found in DummyTest).
You should get the same message box saying "Test class not found in project."
Clicking on "The Dummy Test" opens up the test case in step 4? It's still not
working for me on I20020218 (Win2k, JDK 1.4.1_01)
sorry, i need to recheck on junit 3.8 - i think i missed that (obviously

Bug.WithStack:
To reproduce:
1. Create a TestCase that looks like: --------- package test;
import junit.framework.Test; import junit.framework.TestCase; import junit.framework.TestSuite;
public class DummyTest extends TestCase { public DummyTest(String name) { super(name); }
public static Test suite() { TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(DummyTest.class, "The Dummy Test");
return suite; }
public void testDummy() { fail("Not yet implemented."); } } ---------
2. With it selected, click on {The Running Man}->Run As->JUnit Test 3. In the JUnit Test Results view, click on the "Hierarchy" tab. 4. Double click on "The Dummy Test". You should get a message box saying Test class not found in project 5. Double click on the failed test "testDummy" -- you should have the editor containing DummyTest open up. 6. Remove testDummy. Rerun test. 7. Double click on the "warning" (that there are no tests found in DummyTest). You should get the same message box saying "Test class not found in project." Adam can you pls investigate no probs cannot reproduce 4 can reproduce 7 Clicking on "The Dummy Test" opens up the test case in step 4? It's still not working for me on I20020218 (Win2k, JDK 1.4.1_01) sorry, i need to recheck on junit 3.8 - i think i missed that (obviously crucial) part yup, reproduced both on 3.8
the remove test runner does not communicate with the client too well in this case 'remote', that is i don't think wwe can fix this for 2.1
the problem is in the clent-server protocol, which we don't want to touch at this point
here's what the test runned sends to the client (for the test suite node): "%TSTTREEThe Dummy Test,true,1" there's no way the client can do anything useful with this info
the problem is that TestSuite.toString changes in 3.8 and it can now be something different that Object.toString()
so i think no 2.1 action for the suite node
as for the warning node - this is sent from the remote runner: %TSTTREEwarning(junit.framework.TestSuite$1),false,1
again, client cannot do anything with it (there's no reference to the TestDummy class)
back to Erich - suggest deferring for now agreed no action for 2.1 Erich, Adam -- will there be any action on this bug for 3.0, or is it too late in the game? Tx. :-) we should look into this one - reopening the protocol could improved for when the constructor TestSuite(final Class theClass) is used. However, this requires additional API on TestSuite in JUnit.
Have to defer since it depends on a new version of JUnit As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: Navigate Goto Resource does not find certain files
Bug.WithStack:
If I open a Java perspective and then Navigate | Go to | Resource, not all files are visible only those that are under the java source directory. If I open a navigator view or perspective, all files are seen.
Should the the goto resource should be the same. No, Goto resource is an action that takes you to a specific resource in either the package explorer or the navigator depending on which of these two views have the focus when activating the action. Since the package explorer shows less resources as the navigator the dialog contains less elements.
Please note that with M5 the package explorer will show simple projects as well. So you get almost the same dialog. Only generated class files are missing since thay aren't visible in the package explorer either. Let mee see if read it correctly. The resource navigator should find all things visible in the package explorer. If this is true, then this is still a bug.
The resource navigator from package explorer sees resources only from the java source directories. It also sees the .classpath and .project files. But it does note see anything else. If I have files in the project that I can see from the package explorer, can't find them in the goto resource. No the go to resource actions are specific for the Navigator or the package explorer. Internally these are two different classes. If you give the resource navigator focus and open the go to resource dialog the dialog should show you all resources accessable in the Navigator. Analogous if you open the dialog with an package explorer in focus you should see all resources accessable through the package explorer.
What puzzles me a little bit is your statement: "The resource navigator from package explorer". What do you mean by this ? Created attachment 3182 Navigate Resource example
I include here an snapshot for my confusion. The focus is on the "Package Explorer" and goto: Navigate -> Goto -> Resource. That is what I mean by "The resource navigator from package explorer".
The list shows only resources under "src/java", but it does not show resources from the "etc/services" directory (empty.html, sample-request.xml, text.txt).
If Package Explorer sees them, why Goto Resource does not ? No I get it. We are changing the implementation for M5 and I will make sure that the case is handled properly. Thanks for your patience. Thank You I will take this oportunity to express my gratitude for the whole Eclipse team. Great job, and thank you for listening to us. Fixed for build > I20030214.

If I open a Java perspective and then Navigate | Go to | Resource, not all files are visible only those that are under the java source directory. If I open a navigator view or perspective, all files are seen.
Should the the goto resource should be the same. No, Goto resource is an action that takes you to a specific resource in either the package explorer or the navigator depending on which of these two views have the focus when activating the action. Since the package explorer shows less resources as the navigator the dialog contains less elements.
Please note that with M5 the package explorer will show simple projects as well. So you get almost the same dialog. Only generated class files are missing since thay aren't visible in the package explorer either. Let mee see if read it correctly. The resource navigator should find all things visible in the package explorer. If this is true, then this is still a bug.
The resource navigator from package explorer sees resources only from the java source directories. It also sees the .classpath and .project files. But it does note see anything else. If I have files in the project that I can see from the package explorer, can't find them in the goto resource. No the go to resource actions are specific for the Navigator or the package explorer. Internally these are two different classes. If you give the resource navigator focus and open the go to resource dialog the dialog should show you all resources accessable in the Navigator. Analogous if you open the dialog with an package explorer in focus you should see all resources accessable through the package explorer.
What puzzles me a little bit is your statement: "The resource navigator from package explorer". What do you mean by this ? Created attachment 3182 Navigate Resource example
I include here an snapshot for my confusion. The focus is on the "Package Explorer" and goto: Navigate -> Goto -> Resource. That is what I mean by "The resource navigator from package explorer".
The list shows only resources under "src/java", but it does not show resources from the "etc/services" directory (empty.html, sample-request.xml, text.txt).
If Package Explorer sees them, why Goto Resource does not ? No I get it. We are changing the implementation for M5 and I will make sure that the case is handled properly. Thanks for your patience. Thank You I will take this oportunity to express my gratitude for the whole Eclipse team. Great job, and thank you for listening to us. Fixed for build > I20030214.

Bug.Summery: CVS Directories Removed from Linked Folder
Bug.WithStack:
I am using the linked folder mechanism in latest builds (integration builds on 1/15 and 1/22, as well as M4), and am seeing my CVS directory contents removed for my linked folders.
This is perhaps hard to reproduce. It doesn't happen on initial project refresh, but perhaps subsequent project refresh? Not sure.
What I have is a directory structure like this:
/myproject/src <- real sources /myproject/common <- linked folder
Common points to a directory structure on my filesystem that was checked out using CVS command line tools. Soon after I setup this project structure, the CVS directories in this tree that contain Entries, Root, etc., are removed. They are completely gone! The files themselves are still there, but it's like CVS was not the tool that checked out these dirs!
I also tried the following:
/myproject/src <- real sources /myproject/common <- real folder /myproject/common/src1 <- linked folder (W2K "junction") /myproject/common/src2 <- linked folder (W2K "junction")
With the same results.
This happens on three separate systems; one is NT, two are W2K. What do you mean by "the directories are gone but the files are still there". Do you mean that the CVS folders do not appear in Eclipse but they still exist in the file system. If so, then this is expected behavior (The Eclipse CVS client always hides CVS directories that contained CVS meta information). If not, please reopen with a more concise description of the problem.
FYI: if you add linked resources to a CVS project, these resources will be ignored even if they are also mapped to CVS. If you want to use Eclipse CVS operations on a linked folder, you would also have to import this folder as a project into Eclipse. To your question,
"Do you mean that the CVS folders do not appear in Eclipse but they still exist in the file system. If so, then this is expected behavior"
Yes, I understand that. What I actually mean is, that the CVS directories *are removed from the file system*.
Here's an exact case:
1 /Source 2 /Source/CVS 3 /Source/SomeProject 4 /Source/SomeProject/CVS 5 /Source/SomeProject/com 6 /Source/SomeProject/com/CVS
If I link /Source/SomeProject as an external folder to an eclipse project, and then I do a refresh, directories 4 and 6 listed above *are removed* by the refresh. They never show up in Eclipse, which is (agreed) expected behavior, and preferable. However, if I go to those directories and want to commit them using an external tool, I can no longer cvs dif, cvs up, cvs etc....
While I understand the need to use the built-in CVS integration of Eclipse, with our source structure there are over 200 separate projects, and I want to bring in about 40 of them. We have a master working directory on all our developer's machines that we keep fairly well synced to our common repository using CVS command line tools or WinCVS. I wish to create an Eclipse project that has a primary source directory, and then links to several others in /Source/WHATEVER_I_NEED_THAT_DAY. Those directories in /Source map directly to the CVS repository.
Why does the refresh need to delete files it has no business deleting? The CVS directories should be sacred.
The files shouldn't be removed from the file system. We will investigate. I have committed the fix for this but want to leave it open for now so I can run some addition tests.
As an aside, are you sure you want to connect common source folders to the projects that use them using the linked resource mechanism. This will cause the source to be built in each project in which it is linked. It would seem to me a better approach to load the common source as a separate project and reference it from any other dependant projects. This way, the common source only gets built once. Is there soemthing that prevents you from doing this? You bring up a good point. I had originally attempted to do this with M4, which was really my first experience with Eclipse. I had really waited with bated breath for the updated project structure features, with exclusions, because of well-documented limitations of the Eclipse project facility pre-2.1.
When I did this with M4, debugging became a problem in that breakpoints in my "common" project would not find sources when debugging a project that depended on the "common" project. I'll revisit this, as you are potentially correct that that would be the best way.
I still have the issue of needing 24 or so projects, then, because of the way our sources are laid out. Not ideal.
Thanks for the pointer. Fix released to HEAD

Bug.Summery: auto-indentation in JDT editor appears to have problems
Bug.WithStack:
Since 2.1 M4, auto-indentation in the JDT editor appears to have broken.
I desire hard tabs to be 8, but indentation to be 4. I had it working this way prior to M4, but now auto-indentation is 8.
Perhaps this is a repeat of bug 28454, but it isn't clear. The preference settings for tabs and indentation are confusing.
I have the "Displayed tab width" preference set to 8 (from Java/Editor/Appearance preference page).
In the Code Formatter/Style preference, I have "Indentation represented by a tab" unchecked and "Number of spaces representing a tab" set to 4.
Therefore, I expect auto-indentation to be 4, while hard tabs are 8. If I am misunderstanding the preference settings, could someone explain how I can get the desired behavior restored for M4?
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 28454 ***

Bug.Summery: Team CVS commit comments not preserved across invocations
Bug.WithStack: When committing a change Eclipse preserves recently used commit comments, but this list is lost when you close Eclipse and start again. I'm using I20030122. Boris, check latest -- I recall Michael discussing putting this in. If we're not persisting it, then please put this in. *** Bug 9915 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** If the comment history is to be preserved across runs, which would be great, I suggest that the commit dialog have a "Delete" and "Delete All" button in order to remove comments from the history. Since the commit dialog is now resizable, the comment history could be in a list box instead of a drop down which would make the UI a little easier to use. Created attachment 3327 Simple patch preserving the last comment why has 9915 been marked as a duplicate of this bug? 9915 asks for a history of recent commit comments (ie. not just the last one), this one talks about that list being persisted. Created attachment 3455 Patch against ccvs.ui.ReleaseCommentDialog - don't setText() initially Created attachment 3456 Version preserving 10 comments (apply to ccvs.ui.repo) Created attachment 3485 Patch against team.cvs.ui for handling multiple chunks correctly Fix released to HEAD *** Bug 32078 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: Cancel button doesn't work sometimes in CVS commit comments window
Find/Replace should be possible for projects

Lines.Line: 1. Use File Search for the string you want to replace
2. In the Search view select the items you want to replace
3. From the context menu select "Replace..." or "Replace Selected..."
- bug 16287: Feature request: "Search in project" option

Bug.WithStack:
It should be possible to right-click on a project or a folder in a project and do a find/replace, which would be applied to all non-binary resources of type file under that tree.
Or am I supposed to write a Perl script to do that for me, outside Eclipse ? :- ) Duplicate of 8695? You can do this: 1. Use File Search for the string you want to replace 2. In the Search view select the items you want to replace 3. From the context menu select "Replace..." or "Replace Selected..."
Note there are still known limitations: - bug 24008: (automatic) Global Replace - bug 16287: Feature request: "Search in project" option
Feel free to add yourself to the cc-list of these bug reports.

It should be possible to right-click on a project or a folder in a project and do a find/replace, which would be applied to all non-binary resources of type file under that tree.
Or am I supposed to write a Perl script to do that for me, outside Eclipse ? :- ) Duplicate of 8695? You can do this: 1. Use File Search for the string you want to replace 2. In the Search view select the items you want to replace 3. From the context menu select "Replace..." or "Replace Selected..."
Note there are still known limitations: - bug 24008: (automatic) Global Replace - bug 16287: Feature request: "Search in project" option
Feel free to add yourself to the cc-list of these bug reports.

Bug.Summery: Please add Changlogs to builds /Download Page
Bug.WithStack: Would be nice, so one can check, what's new/fixed/buggy in the current build (may it be stable or integration build). PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 Future means you commit to fix it in the Future. Inboxes can't make committments. Moving to '--'. We don't do changelogs anymore, "Target milestone" in bugzilla is used for that.
Bug.WithOutStack: Would be nice, so one can check, what's new/fixed/buggy in the current build (may it be stable or integration build). PR was not targeted to any particular release. Changing target milestone to 2.1 Future means you commit to fix it in the Future. Inboxes can't make committments. Moving to '--'. We don't do changelogs anymore, "Target milestone" in bugzilla is used for that.

Bug.Summery: Used to workDeleting CVS dirs causes serious problems

Lines.Line: 1. Delete the directory, let's call it "D" (and its subdirectories) where the
2. Invoke JAXB's XJC which creates .java files in the directory "D" and a
1) Made a project with a few nested directories
3) deleted the CVS folders from the directories

Bug.WithStack:
This used to work before 2.1.M4.
I have an ant build.xml used to invoke Sun's JAXB XJC source code generator. The build.xml does the following: 1. Delete the directory, let's call it "D" (and its subdirectories) where the source is to be generated. 2. Invoke JAXB's XJC which creates .java files in the directory "D" and a subdir.
I invoked ant from the command prompt from the directory "D". I then did a Refresh in eclipse of "D", which recompiles everything. Good. I then did a Team/Commit to CVS. Great.
This no longer works!
I get all sorts of error messages from eclipse first about CVS/Entries not being there, then about not being able to make a connection. This is very bad news for me.
If I try to do a Team/Replace With Latest from Repository, I do NOT get back the previous version from CVS. So I am stuck. I have tried the following in M4 (I assume you're using M4 since you said it worked before then):
1) Made a project with a few nested directories 2) exited eclipse 3) deleted the CVS folders from the directories 4) started Eclipse
Here are my findings:
- I get the error about the missing CVS/Entries file if I do not perform a refresh before trying to commit (which I would expect since they were there before they were deleted in the file system). After the refresh I do not get this error. We should try to have a more helpful error message.
- I get the error about the missing connection when I try to commit from the Navigator. It is caused by a bug in the add to version control logic.
Syncing and performing an "Override and Commit" (instead of using Commit from the navigator) worked for me. Does it work for you?
Also, you say that Replace With Latest doesn't work? Can you give more details about the nature of the failure? Fix has been released. One remaining issue is deleting a CVS folder in a parent while leaving one in a child. I have opend bug 30322 to deal with the remaining issue.
Bug.WithOutStack:
This used to work before 2.1.M4.
I have an ant build.xml used to invoke Sun's JAXB XJC source code generator. The build.xml does the following: 1. Delete the directory, let's call it "D" (and its subdirectories) where the source is to be generated. 2. Invoke JAXB's XJC which creates .java files in the directory "D" and a subdir.
I invoked ant from the command prompt from the directory "D". I then did a Refresh in eclipse of "D", which recompiles everything. Good. I then did a Team/Commit to CVS. Great.
This no longer works!
I get all sorts of error messages from eclipse first about CVS/Entries not being there, then about not being able to make a connection. This is very bad news for me.
If I try to do a Team/Replace With Latest from Repository, I do NOT get back the previous version from CVS. So I am stuck. I have tried the following in M4 (I assume you're using M4 since you said it worked before then):
1) Made a project with a few nested directories 2) exited eclipse 3) deleted the CVS folders from the directories 4) started Eclipse
Here are my findings:
- I get the error about the missing CVS/Entries file if I do not perform a refresh before trying to commit (which I would expect since they were there before they were deleted in the file system). After the refresh I do not get this error. We should try to have a more helpful error message.
- I get the error about the missing connection when I try to commit from the Navigator. It is caused by a bug in the add to version control logic.
Syncing and performing an "Override and Commit" (instead of using Commit from the navigator) worked for me. Does it work for you?
Also, you say that Replace With Latest doesn't work? Can you give more details about the nature of the failure? Fix has been released. One remaining issue is deleting a CVS folder in a parent while leaving one in a child. I have opend bug 30322 to deal with the remaining issue.

Bug.Summery: [Tasks] Filter view menu item
Bug.WithStack:
build 20030121
The view menu item "Filter..." should be "Filters...." The title of the task filter dialog should be "Task Filters". These are the names used by the package and navigator views. fixed.

build 20030121
The view menu item "Filter..." should be "Filters...." The title of the task filter dialog should be "Task Filters". These are the names used by the package and navigator views. fixed.
